Description: Greek terracotta figure of female. Fragment of head. Hole pierced near top. The mouth has a simple smile, the cheeks are rounded, and the ears are invisible, concealed by a veil or other head-dress with a flat top of some stiff material. The hair, which is visible over the centre of the forehead and in a thick mass over the remaining temple. Mould-made and hollow, with no back. Traces of white coating. Buff fine fabric with light brown core.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

From the Hellenion, Gutch dated this to the mid 5th century BC (in Hogarth 1899, 78). The Fitzwilliam Museum have it dated to the late 5th century BC. The sherd is marked with the Gutch number '9' and '97'.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 78, no. 9, pl. X, no. 9)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.393) (Phase 3)
